awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Bridging the gap between particle-scale thermal transport and device-scale predictions
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding how heat is transported in gas-particle mixtures is critical to improving the performance, efficiency and reliability of clean energy technologies and predicting environmental flows. The conversion of coal and biomass into useful fuel, thermal storage by particulate material, and particle-based solar receivers, all represent promising technologies that rely heavily on heat transfer in multiphase systems. Current tools used in industry and academia rely on simplistic models for average reaction rates as well as heat transfer coefficients that are known to vary by several orders of magnitude. This project introduces a new modeling approach that will enable researchers to address the huge range of challenges associated with heat transfer through gas-particle mixtures. For a broader educational impact, a toy version of a fluidized bed will be built with beads sprayed with thermochromic liquid crystals that change color with temperature. This will be presented at local schools to illustrate fundamental concepts of fluid-particle interactions.

In this project, researchers from Michigan, Iowa State, and Minnesota collaborate to develop a new paradigm in multiphase heat transfer modeling. The aim is to bridge the gap between particle-scale thermal processes and device-scale predictions. A consistent modeling framework is formulated that scales from a well-accepted physics-based model to a larger scale of interest. Current approaches typically ensemble-average data obtained from the microscale physics directly, without taking into account local variations on scales resolvable by the simulation framework. The proposed effort will connect the spatially-averaged, large-scale representation to two-phase statistics obtained from particle-resolved numerical simulations. A previously overlooked ergodic consistency requirement will be enforced so that the numerical solution converges to the ensemble-averaged two-fluid equations in the limit of large filter width. Model validation will be based on simultaneous multi-camera imaging at different scales, and a novel application of Voronoi tessellation to quantify clustering in dense suspensions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding how heat is transported in gas-particle mixtures is critical to improving the performance, efficiency, and reliability of clean and affordable energy generation and for predicting the environmental impact of pollution and climate change. State-of-the-art computer simulations rely on existing models for average gas-solid heat transfer coefficients that result in enormous predictive uncertainty. To achieve truly predictive heat transfer calculations in gas-solid suspensions, a consistent modeling framework has been established that scales from a well-accepted physics-based model to a larger scale of interest.

Simulating realistic particle-laden flow systems requires cutting-edge computational resources that can perform ultrafast computational operations on massive amounts of data. These requirements arise from representing the finest flow details such as flow around each individual particles in industrial devices or natural systems that contain trillions of particles. The volume-filtered Euler-Lagrange (VFEL) approach developed by University of Michigan researchers renders the simulation of very large systems amenable to computation by smoothing out the finest flow details around individual particles, while approximating the essential interactions of particles with the flow. Researchers at Iowa State University (ISU) have focused on developing modeling tools suitable for this approach that are able to further simplify and speed up such computations by improving these approximations on the basis of ISU's high-fidelity fully-resolved PUReIBM simulations that inform well-accepted physics-based models. Unlike previous work, the new closure methodology connects the volume-filtered, large-scale representation, which depends on the filter width, to the two-phase statistics obtained from particle-resolved direction numerical simulations.

These improved models will enable highly accurate simulation of heat transfer in gas-particle suspensions that constitute critical processes in different energy technologies and environmental flows. Such improved models will result in performance gains, improved efficiency, and reliability of industrial clean energy technologies. They will also enable better prediction of pollution arising from environmental disasters and impacts on air and water quality resulting from the effects of climate change.

Intellectual Merit: In this project we tested and verified an ergodic consistency hypothesis using ISU's high-fidelity particle-resolved direction numerical simulation code PUReIBM. This places the proposed consistent modeling framework that scales from a well-accepted physics-based model to a larger scale of interest, on a firm foundation. Data on flow velocity and temperature fields obtained from PUReIBM simulations was used to develop scalable models of fluid kinetic energy and gas-solid heat transfer. The research was disseminated in five published journal papers, one journal paper in preparation, four conference papers and one invited talk. Two Masters thesis were completed by two graduate students as part of the project.

Broader Impact Outcomes: The improved models of pseudo-turbulent kinetic energy and pseudo-turbulent heat flux were implemented in the NGA and OpenFOAM codes. These improvements will result in more accurate simulation of gas-solid suspensions.
